abstract:
Modern telescopes automatically detect far more galaxies than
astronomers can ever actually look at. To turn a million galaxy images
into something meaningful, science needs to learn from data science.

I'll give a crash course on galaxies and introduce you to `The
Zooniverse <www.zooniverse.org>`__, a free platform for researchers to
crowdsource labels. I'll show how I use TensorFlow and the PyData stack
to build a galaxy image classification algorithm from noisy crowdsourced
labels and then ensemble them together to outperform both humans and
machines. I'll highlight where science and data science diverge, and
what we can learn from each other.

-  Everything you should know about galaxies in 60 seconds

   -  What do we want to discover?

-  Welcome to `The Zooniverse <www.zooniverse.org>`__

   -  Open science: how to get the `telescope
      data <http://legacysurvey.org/viewer?ra=147.45674&dec=1.09255&zoom=14&layer=decals-dr5>`__
      and `labels <http://data.galaxyzoo.org>`__
   -  Using crowdsourced labels effectively
   -  Troll-slaying: aggregation to discount bad actors
   -  Why science isn't Agile

-  Classifying galaxy images with TensorFlow

   -  Human-machine ensembles for supervised learning
   -  Kaggle nostalgia: how can we prove it works?
description:
Deep learning is making astrophysicists excited and afraid. We're
excited because we can show a neural network every galaxy in the sky and
ask questions, and afraid because we don't understand the answers. I'll
talk about how you can investigate galaxy evolution with TensorFlow and
crowdsourced labels, what we're discovering, and where it all falls
apart.
title: Data, Science: Investigating 1 Million Galaxies with Humans and TensorFlow
